error.promises: There was a problem retrieving the manifest from your site.

screenshot.error: The url needs to be an absolute url.

windows.test_package: Want to test your app first before going to the Microsoft Store? Tap Download to get a package you can install and test.

base_package.download: Download your generated Web Manifest and chosen Service Worker to make your app a PWA!

basepack.run_new: After uploading the above files to your Web App tap Run New Test to test your PWA again!

windows_platform.p: Your download will contain instructions for submitting your app to the Microsoft Store. Your app will be powered by the Chromium-based Edge platform.

top_section.p: Looks like your web app is not a PWA yet, but you're on your way! Head below to download your base file package and get one step closer to packaging your app for the app stores.

summary_body.p: Whether you edited your manifest or added a service worker, in your downloaded base package files you will receive a manifest and service worker files ready to be added to your server, along with some helpful documentation.
Easily update and upgrade your Web Manifest with our built-in Web Manifest editor

screenshots.p: Specify the URLs to generate desktop and mobile screenshots from. You may add up to 8 screenshots or Store Listings.

descriptions.description: Used in app storefronts and install dialogs
descriptions.start_url: The relative URL that loads when your app starts
descriptions.scope: Which URLs can load within your app
descriptions.display: The appearance of your app window
descriptions.orientation: The default screen orientation of your app
descriptions.language: The primary language of your app

description.package_name: The unique identifier of your app. It should contain only letters, numbers, and periods. Example: com.companyname.appname
description.launcher_name: The app name used on the Android launch screen. Typically, this is the short name of the app.
description.app_version: The version of your app displayed to users. This is a string, typically in the form of '1.0.0.0'. Maps to android:versionName.
description.app_version_code: A positive integer used as an internal version number. This is not shown to users. Android uses this value to protect against downgrades. Maps to android:versionCode.
description.start_url: The start path for the TWA. Must be relative to the Host URL. You can specify '/' if you don't have a start URL different from Host.
description.start_url_short: The start path for the TWA. Must be relative to the Host URL.
description.theme_color: Also known as the theme color, this is the color of the Android status bar in your app. Note: the status bar will be hidden if Display Mode is set to fullscreen.
description.splash_color: Also known as background color, this is the color of the splash screen for your app.
description.nav_color: The color of the Android navigation bar in your app. Note: the navigation bar will be hidden if Display Mode is set to fullscreen.
description.dark_color: The color of the Android navigation bar in your app when Android is in dark mode.
description.div_color: The color of the Android navigation bar divider in your app.
description.div_dark_color: The color of the Android navigation navigation bar divider in your app when Android is in dark mode.
description.mask_icon_url: Optional. The URL to an icon with a minimum safe zone of trimmable padding, enabling rounded icons on certain Android platforms.
description.mono_icon_url: Optional. The URL to an icon containing only white and black colors, enabling Android to fill the icon with user-specified color or gradient depending on theme, color mode, or contrast settings.
description.custom: Use Chrome Custom Tabs as a fallback for your PWA when the full trusted web activity (TWA) experience is unavailable.
description.web_view: Use a web view as the fallback for your PWA when the full trusted web activity (TWA) experience is unavailable.
description.standalone: Your PWA will use the whole screen but keep the Android status bar and navigation bar.
description.fullscreen: Your PWA will use the whole screen and remove the Android status bar and navigation bar. Suitable for immersive experiences such as games or media apps.
description.notification: Whether to enable Push Notification Delegation. If enabled, your PWA can send push notifications without browser permission prompts.
description.location_delegation: Whether to enable Location Delegation. If enabled, your PWA can acess navigator.geolocation without browser permission prompts.
description.google_play_billing: Whether to enable in-app purchases through Google Play Billing and the Digital Goods API.
description.settings_shortcut: If enabled, users can long-press on your app tile and a Settings menu item will appear, letting users manage space for your app.
description.chromeos_only: If enabled, your Android package will only run on ChromeOS devices.
description.metaquest: If enabled, your Android package will be compatible with Meta Quest devices.
description.form_details: Your download will contain instructions for submitting your app to the Google Play Store.
description.source_code: If enabled, your download will include the source code for your Android app.
description.signing_key: PWABuilder will generate a new signing key for you and sign your APK with it. Your download will contain the new signing key and passwords.
description.unsigned_key: PWABuilder will generate an unsigned APK. Google Play Store will sign your package. This is Google's recommended approach.
description.upload_signing_key: Upload your existing signing key. Use this option if you already have a signing key and you want to publish a new version of an existing app in Google Play.
description.key_country_code: The 2 letter country code to list on the signing key
description.key_pw: The password for the signing key. Type a new password or leave empty to use a generated password.
description.key_store_pw: The password for the key store. Type a new password or leave empty to use a generated password.

description.blog: Check out the PWABuilder blog for all the latest on PWABuilder and PWAs
description.demo: Check out our demos to see what PWAs are capable of!
description.documentation: Looking for our documentation? Tap View Documentation to get started!

description.manifest: A Web App Manifest of a website governs how your Progressive Web App (PWA) looks and behaves when installed on a device.
description.sw: Service Workers are a special type of Web Worker with the ability to intercept, modify, and respond to all offline and online network requests using the Fetch API.
description.https: Having a secure HTTPS endpoint and other user safeguards making the user experience secure from end to end.

titles.discord: Join us on our Discord Server

description.github: Contribute to this open source project by joining our PWA community on GitHub.
description.twitter: Meet our fellow PWA enthusiast and follow our latest releases and updates on Twitter.
description.discord: Join the PWABuilder Discord community to connect with the people and resources you need.

description.trivago: Engagement for users who add to homescreen has increased by 150%. This increased engagement led to a 97% increase in click outs to hotel offers.
description.alibaba: After upgrading to a PWA, Alibaba saw a 76% increase in total conversions across browsers. And 30% more monthly active users on Android.
description.pintrest: With the new Pinterest PWA they were able to increase user-generated ad revenue by 44% and core engagement by 60%.
description.tinder: The native Tinder application was a whopping 30MB, when Tinder transitioned to PWA they were able to reduce their file size down to 2.8MB.

manifest_options.upload: Your app's icon. This is the icon operating systems will use to represent your app. In Windows this is used in the taskbar, start menu etc, launch screen.
manifest_options.generate: Screenshots of your PWA can be used in stores and the in-browser install prompt to help promote your PWA.
manifest_options.background_color: The background_color member controls the splash screen color of your app.
manifest_options.theme_color: The theme_color member defines the default theme color for your app. On Windows, this will be the color of your app's title bar.
manifest_options.name: The name of your app as displayed to the user.
manifest_options.short_name: The short name for your app. It's used where there is insufficent space to display the full name.
manifest_options.start_url: A URL relative to the root of your domain that is opened when your app is launched, e.g. /index.html. Typically this is set to '/', indicating the root of the domain.
manifest_options.scope: The scope member is a string that defines the navigation scope of this web application's application context.
manifest_options.display: How your app is displayed. Standalone: Recommended. Your PWA appears like a native app, no browser UI is shown. Minimal-ui: similar to standalone but includes a refresh button and back button in your app's title bar. Fullscreen: Typically used in immersive games, your PWA takes up all the available display area without any browser UI or app title bar. Browser: full browser UI is shown.
manifest_options.orientation: The default orientation your app should be used in, such as portrait or landscape.
manifest_options.language: Specifies the primary language of the app.
manifest_options.description: A description of your app. Appears in app listings, app storefronts, and app install UI.

imageGenerator.image_generator_text: Quickly and easily create app icons for various platforms in the right size and format
imageGenerator.input_image_help: You should choose a 512x512 or larger square PNG/SVG/WEBP image. This image will be used to generate all the images for your chosen platforms.
imageGenerator.padding_text: 0 is no padding, 1 is 100% of the source image. 0.3 is a typical value for most icons. For Windows 11 platform, this value is overriden on individual images based on UX guidelines.
imageGenerator.platforms_text: Select the platforms to generate images for.
